title: Day 1276
content:
# Day 1276

Thinking from first principles quietly leaves the chat (my brain) the moment my thumb opens social media (A.K.A X/Twitter). I tell myself "just one scroll" with the same confidence as someone saying "just one line of cocaine" at a Wall Street Christmas party. Ten minutes later I've learned three life hacks from a profile whose bio is just "manifesting abundance through silicone" followed by watching a guy in his mom's basement explain why Tesla's free energy patents were suppressed by Big Oil while he vapes God knows what. The rabbit hole isn't paved with good intentions anymore, like it was when I was a teenager reading subtweets from my high school buddy who was mad at me for not sharing my Cherry Coke. Now it's paved with targeted ads and the algorithmic equivalent of a dealer who knows exactly what gets you hooked.

Our grandfathers had battlefields. We have notification badges. The arrows are pings. The siege engines are "Recommended For You." Modern man's challenge is not storming beaches. It's resisting a glowing rectangle that storms our attention 10 million ways a day.

!['Friends, previous generations faced bullets. We face blue-light dopamine traps. I stand here to remind myself: the blank page is harder than the feed, but it actually compounds.'](https://miro.medium.com/1*FioRY-Z5LmKjL0UN7BROVw.png)

Writing is one my antidotes. Reading actual books is another. It asks for effort up front, then pays out a clean dopamine drip that I actually earned. When I sit down, I have to push through that first wall of friction. Then the mind clears. I start asking better questions: What truly makes me happy? How can I use this daily page to think from first principles and build the life I want? What knowledge can be gained from this book I am reading?

Truth is, I already have much of what I want in life and reminding myself of this is good. A beautiful wife. A brilliant daughter. A home. Family nearby. By God's grace and some luck, I'm rich where it counts. And still, there is more I want to build. So let's think in first principles and set some ten-year targets.

**Ten-Year Targets**

1. **Debt-free.** No mortgage, no student loans, no "just this one last payment."

2. **Business owner.** Open a movie theater in Jax that I would actually want to go to. A place with soul.

That's it. Two aims. How do I get there? Increase income so I can crush debt and stack capital. Find mentors who have already walked this road. Court luck by shipping work consistently. Opening a theater won't be easy, but difficult is not the same as impossible.

To win in the modern battlefield, I need a simple rule of engagement: write before I scroll. If I must scroll, scroll after I've shipped. The algorithm can have my leftovers, not my prime hours.

So yes, I'm guilty of scrolling too much. But I'm also capable of thinking from first principles, one honest session at a time. Forcing myself to write every day, especially on days like today when I didn't want to, compounds in ways the feed never will. Fewer thumb reps. More brain reps. Less rabbit hole. More rabbit habitat for my ideas.

Ten years from now, I want to look back and thank my past self for choosing the blank page over the endless scroll. I want to walk into that Jacksonville theater I built, a place where the lights dim, the room hushes, and two hours of unbroken attention feels normal again. Where kids don't fidget through act two because they've forgotten how to sit with a single story.

The feed resets every refresh. The page compounds forever.

If we're going to change what kids can't do, we have to change what we won't do. Starting with putting the phone down and picking up the pen. Or at least your _Medium_ sized screen (laptop) and writing on _Medium_. But now, as I type this out, I realize I should look into tech where I can write something with a pen then have my writing turned into text.

I guess I could just take a picture and ask AI to transcribe it if I wrote on legit pen & paper. That would definitely work.

Anyways, I've rambled long enough. But do you see what happens to your ideas when you sit and think through them. Powerful stuff. And some clowns on social media are blasting idea guys as not useful. But every action must come first from an idea. So it's best to try and have as many good ideas as possible. Ok now I'm done (until tomorrow).

9/18/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
